Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I sat on the edge of our bed, my husband’s hand trembling in mine. He’d barely slept in days, his eyes red from grief and worry. He needed me—he said it over and over, that my presence was the only thing keeping him afloat. I wanted nothing more than to stay, to hold him, to reassure him that he wasn’t alone in this storm. But my phone buzzed again. It was the synagogue’s coordinator. They needed one more person for the minyan, the quorum required for the funeral prayer. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen, and the grieving family would be left waiting, unable to say goodbye according to our tradition. My heart twisted. My husband’s pain was raw and immediate, but so was the call of my faith, the responsibility to my community. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore. I looked at my husband, then at my phone, torn between the two parts of myself, not knowing which to answer.
